2690.name: NICU Friendly T-Bonnet
2690.gauge_description: 20 stitches and 25 rows = 2 inches in stockinette stitch
2690.notes_html:
Download pattern in .pdf format here.



Additional Information:

    Medium Preemie:

        Needle Size:  2.25 mm (US 1)

        Yarn Weight: Baby (DK) Yarn

        Gauge:  18 stitches & 23 rows = 2 inches

        Yardage:  1/2 oz.



    Large Preemie:

        Needle Size:  3.25mm (US 3)

        Yarn Weight:  Fingering (Sock) yarn

        Gauge:  14 stitches & 18 rows = 2 inches

        Yardage:  1 oz.



    Notions needed:

        1 yard of 1/4" - 3/8" satin ribbon

        3 3/8" buttons

7389.name: PICC Arm Band
7389.gauge_description: 5 stitches  = 1 inch in stockinette stitch on 3.75 mm needles
7389.notes_html:
From the Knit Picks Website:
Choose from any of our soft machine washable yarns to create this fashionable cover-up. Simply determine your gauge and knit a tube that is 8” in diameter and 6” long with ribbing at each end.

Yarn
Knit Picks Swish Worsted
(100% Superwash Merino Wool ; 110 yards/50 grams):
MC - 110 yards
CC - 110 yards

Needles
Size 5: set of dpn
Adjust needle size if necessary to obtain correct gauge.

Notions:
Yarn needle

Design features ribbed edges and stockinette stitch body with stripe accents. Worked entirely in the round on double pointed needles.

Ed. note: Two arm bands could be made by switching MC and CC.

PICC: Peripherally-inserted central catheter
7389.notes:
*From the Knit Picks Website:*

Needles

Adjust needle size if necessary to obtain correct gauge.

Design features ribbed edges and stockinette stitch body with stripe accents. Worked entirely in the round on double pointed needles.

*Ed. note: Two arm bands could be made by switching MC and CC.*

*PICC: Peripherally-inserted central catheter*

users.about_me:
Knit Picks is dedicated to making knitting accessible and enjoyable. Our passionate team of crafters develop products, curate patterns, and offer extensive tutorial resources to support knitters of all levels. By working directly with trusted manufacturers and eliminating the middleman, Knit Picks ensures ethical practices while maintaining high-quality products at affordable prices.
 
Committed to fostering a diverse and inclusive community, Knit Picks collaborates with a wide range of designers, models, and small businesses. We emphasize amplifying marginalized voices within the crafting world, offering a platform for diverse perspectives. Beyond selling yarn and tools, Knit Picks aims to provide a comprehensive and supportive knitting experience for everyone.

Please visit us at http://www.knitpicks.com or contact us at customerservice@knitpicks.com.

16988.name: NICU Petal Hat
16988.notes_html:
A sport weight yarn may also be used when knitting this pattern.

A 3/4” button or a knit/crochet flower will be needed to close the top of this hat.

Direct pdf link: http://www.p2designs.com/pdfs/petalhat.pdf
16988.notes:
A sport weight yarn may also be used when knitting this pattern.

A 3/4" button or a knit/crochet flower will be needed to close the top of this hat.

Direct pdf link: http://www.p2designs.com/pdfs/petalhat.pdf

65572.name: Special Body Warmer
65572.notes_html:
Description from the website:

This little body warmer has been made by special request from some of the staff on the neo natal units. It has buttons on the shoulders and opens flat so that the nurses can dress baby with the minimum disturbance. The original was knit in 4ply and measures approx 13” round the chest. It can be made smaller or larger by using larger needles and DK wool or smaller needles and 3 ply wool. As always check with your nearest Neonatal unit to see what their requirements are.

The pattern has instructions for either fingering (4-ply) or sport (5-ply).

The pattern has instructions for either fingering (4-ply) or sport (5-ply).

112468.name: Crocheted PICC Cover
112468.gauge_description: 4 stitches  = 1 inch in crochet in the back loop
112468.notes_html:
There are no images on the archived pattern.

I found sock yarn with lycra in it to work very well. Please check with whomever or whereever you are sending your covers to as to what they prefer for yarn.

Pattern is also available at the Finding Jenn Project website.

packs.personal_name: any stretchy washable yarn or wool

pattern_author.name: WoolyUkulele
pattern_author.notes:
I've been involved in a lifelong affair with fibre :). 

I can’t remember not knitting or crocheting, all the women and some of the men in my family do too. I’ve always made my own patterns but not written them down until lately. Its a lot of work to be very organized and write and check every line.

Fond of anything natural. A bit crazy about mohair ..even the ‘fake’ type. Not sure where that came from. In my dreams i make all my own wool. Actually, in reality i do make a fair bit. I love to start from the dirty fleece and every part is fun, from washing thru dyeing. And knitting or crocheting of course :). I’m happiest creating!

I love to start from the dirty fleece and every part is fun, from washing thru dyeing. And knitting or crocheting of course :).  I'm happiest creating!

139203.name: Button Up IV Gloves
139203.notes_html: I designed these after an overnight stay in an ER with an IV. My hand was cold but I couldn’t put gloves on. These allow you to button the glove around the IV.
139203.notes: I designed these after an overnight stay in an ER with an IV. My hand was cold but I couldn't put gloves on. These allow you to button the glove around the IV.

pattern_author.name: Theresa Harmless Archer
pattern_author.notes:
I started creating my own patterns a couple months after I started knitting in 2006. I started keeping a note book titled Knitting Knotes in 2008 when I created the credit card sock and someone wanted the pattern. 
      I started writing crochet patterns in the summer of 2009.
pattern_author.notes_html:
I started creating my own patterns a couple months after I started knitting in 2006. I started keeping a note book titled Knitting Knotes in 2008 when I created the credit card sock and someone wanted the pattern.
I started writing crochet patterns in the summer of 2009.

users.fave_curse: cuss from the fantastic mr fox
users.about_me:
My Maiden name was Harmless, My married name was Archer. I didn't want to hyphenate but I think its a fun play on words. 
My hobbies are not typically found in the same person. I love to knit, crochet, spin, shoot for Target practice, and restore classic volkswagen beetles, show rabbits.
I started knitting as a way to get to know my grandmother. I just have a knack to it. I really took off and am found knitting or crocheting almost anywhere. 
I started Spinning in 2010 when I got a wheel for my 29th birthday.  I started the Angora herd in 2013 after my dad died. I picked up a second wheel for my 39th birthday. 
Most of my projects are for myself or gifts, although A few are  commissioned pieces. 
My daughters Sydney & Deianeira love their knit and crochet toys and clothes.
I'm not afraid to try a new pattern or make one up of my own if it suits me.
users.about_me_html:
My Maiden name was Harmless, My married name was Archer. I didn’t want to hyphenate but I think its a fun play on words.
My hobbies are not typically found in the same person. I love to knit, crochet, spin, shoot for Target practice, and restore classic volkswagen beetles, show rabbits.
I started knitting as a way to get to know my grandmother. I just have a knack to it. I really took off and am found knitting or crocheting almost anywhere.
I started Spinning in 2010 when I got a wheel for my 29th birthday. I started the Angora herd in 2013 after my dad died. I picked up a second wheel for my 39th birthday.
Most of my projects are for myself or gifts, although A few are commissioned pieces.
My daughters Sydney & Deianeira love their knit and crochet toys and clothes.
I’m not afraid to try a new pattern or make one up of my own if it suits me.

174267.name: PICC Line Cover
174267.notes_html:
PICC Line Cover pattern from Finding Jenn Project Blog:
<a href=“http://findingjennproject.blogspot.com/2009/02/original-p...
”>Original Picc Cover Blog Post</a>

Please consider knitting up some PICC Line Covers for those fighting Cystic Fibrosis (and others that need PICC lines). Visit the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation http://www.cff.org to find a center near you.
Click HERE for map to find U.S. CF Care centers.

Uses up a small amount of worsted superwash wool and makes such a big difference in someone’s life! Acrylic yarns are fine as well, please avoid cotton as it doesn’t have enough bounce-back to hold the 2X2 ribbing shape well.

PICC Line Covers are handy for people fighting various illnesses and diseases. Lime disease, breast cancer, lukemia, the list goes on and on. If you have someone close to you that’s got something medical, ask if they use a picc line and this may work for them as well!

Pattern has been updated to include directions for knitting in the round as well as knitting flat.
174267.notes: PICC Line Cover pattern from Finding Jenn Project Blog: Original Picc Cover Blog Post Please consider knitting up some PICC Line Covers for those fighting Cystic Fibrosis (and others that need PICC lines). Visit the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation http://www.cff.org to find a center near you. Click HERE for map to find U.S. CF Care centers. Uses up a small amount of worsted superwash wool and makes such a big difference in someone's life! Acrylic yarns are fine as well, please avoid cotton as it doesn't have enough bounce-back to hold the 2X2 ribbing shape well. PICC Line Covers are handy for people fighting various illnesses and diseases. Lime disease, breast cancer, lukemia, the list goes on and on. If you have someone close to you that's got something medical, ask if they use a picc line and this may work for them as well! Pattern has been updated to include directions for knitting in the round as well as knitting flat.

packs.yarn_name: TreasureGoddess Yarn Treasured Warmth Worsted Weight

pattern_author.name: Christine Long Derks
pattern_author.notes:
I'm a one woman business that gets by with a lot of help from my fibery friends! I dye intense, saturated tonal colors on luxury yarn bases. My logo is a Pirate Sheep and all my colorway names are pirate/ocean/mermaid related! Some of my favorites are Ghost Ship (charcoal gray), Mermaid's Curse (rich teal), Fathoms Deep (gorgeous navy blue) and Lusty Wench (fabulous orange)!

I've just moved to the country and now have a HUGE dye studio and am loving expanding my colorways, yarn stock and I even host Yarn Parties there a few times a year! (just south of KC).

My yarnie adventures are shared in a sporadic email newsletter. My yarn pirate friends get the best discounts, early access to sales and more! Sign up at https://www.TreasureGoddess.com/Newsletter. 

I've got a fun youtube channel too! Treasure Goddess Yarn https://www.youtube.com/user/TreasureGoddessChic

Happy Creating and enjoy your YARRRRRNNN!

users.about_me:
I'm Christine of Treasure Goddess Yarn. I create hand dyed luxury yarn that takes your breath away! My yarn looks as amazing all knit up, crocheted up & woven up as it does in the skein.

Treasure Goddess Yarn is a one-woman business that gets by with a lot of help from her friends. We host YARN PARTIES at my barn full of yarn twice a year, so if you're in the KC area, come and party with us!

Want to be a yarn pirate too? Sign up for the Treasure Goddess Yarn Newsletter to get the best discounts, free patterns and join the yarnie adventure! https://www.TreasureGoddess.com/newsletter

My yarn names all have pirate and ocean themes for a bit of whimsical fun, plus I'm a Yarn Pirate! YARRRRNNNNNNN

176088.name: Full Arm Warmers with PICC Access

205085.name: NICU VitaCap
205085.notes_html:
The unique feature of this hat is that it opens up and lies almost flat. Baby is placed on top, and the hat is wrapped around any IVs, monitor attachments or wires, then buttoned. This allows for easy access to change wires, as well as keeping them in place and out of the way – all the while keeping baby nice and warm.

Please feel free to use this pattern for your own use or for charity knitting.
205085.notes:
The unique feature of this hat is that it opens up and lies almost flat.  Baby is placed on top, and the hat is wrapped around any IVs, monitor attachments or wires, then buttoned.  This allows for easy access to change wires, as well as keeping them in place and out of the way – all the while keeping baby nice and warm.

Please feel free to use this pattern for your own use or for charity knitting.

225869.name: CPAP hat upwards
225869.sizes_available: To fit premature infants up to newborns.

users.about_me:
I love to knit. Knit on trains, at conferences and in front of the television. Knit a lot for children - somehow I constantly know someone having a baby (and it is so much fun knitting for babies!) and I am the very happy aunt of 10 nephews and nieces (16 - 33 years of age. Some of them grew to much though. Their feet are too large as well, I don´t like knitting socks that big) - and a lot for me.
Love to knit with colours, and not necessarily with very expensive yarn. During the last years I have found the sweaters by Gary Kennedy, and by the Danish designer Marianne Isager. Earlier on I have been knitting Kaffe Fasset. I like Dale knitting patterns as well.
I do chrochet too, but knitting is my favorite.

414936.name: Picc Arm Band
414936.notes_html: This was designed for a friend going through chemotherapy. It is a easy and quick pattern to knit up and use your leftover sock wool. This project would also make great charity/fund-raising knitting.

users.fave_colors: pale yellow, robin's egg blue, periwinkle
users.about_me: Though it is sad to be back supplying, I have more time to knit. Not that my class last year took ALL my time and energy... So far I am trying new things this year in my knitting (traveling sock and mystery sock with Knitters Brewing co.) and looking forward to challenging my skills. I love all things woolly and am just about always working on a knit/crochet or weaving project. Then there is reading about knitting (anything from the Yarn Harlot) and listening to pod casts! I think I MAY have a slight obsession....

515430.name: Folded PICC Sleeve
515430.gauge_description: 27 stitches and 44 rows = 4 inches in stocking stitch
515430.notes_html: This is a unique PICC band or sleeve with a place to insert the PICC and an extra length to fold over the PICC. My son-in-law’s PICC was inserted at the elbow joint. Instead of lying flat the PICC is perpendicular to the joint. He therefore needed a PICC sleeve through which the PICC could be inserted and then covered.
515430.notes: This is a unique PICC band or sleeve with a place to insert the PICC and an extra length to fold over the PICC.  My son-in-law's PICC was inserted at the elbow joint.  Instead of lying flat the PICC is perpendicular to the joint. He therefore needed a PICC sleeve through which the PICC could be inserted and then covered.

users.about_me:
I DO NOT SELL OR TRADE *ANY* OF MY STASH SO PLEASE DON'T ASK.  I do give away skeins as presents to friends and family BUT THAT'S IT!

I live in New York City and NW New Jersey with my spouse, who will be known as the D.B. or Dearly Beloved.  Other fiber arts: spinning, dyeing, sewing, quilting, embroideries of various sorts, needlepoint, macrame (in the 70's & 80's), a smattering of hooking and a little weaving.

570153.name: PICC Line Cover
570153.gauge_description: 16 stitches and 12 rows = 4 inches in HDC (BLO)
570153.notes_html:
Notes: Made flat & seamed with Slip Stitch. Written in US Terms.

Skill: Beginner

Abbreviations: Ch – chain; ESC – extended single crochet; HDC – half double crochet; BLO – back loop only; YO – yarn over

ESC (extended single crochet): Insert hook in next stitch (BLO), YO, draw up loop. YO, draw through one loop. YO, draw through remaining 2 loops on hook.

Sizing for XS, S, M, L, and XL is included.
570153.notes:
Notes:  Made flat & seamed with Slip Stitch.  Written in US Terms.

Skill:  Beginner

Abbreviations:  Ch – chain; ESC – extended single crochet; HDC – half double crochet; BLO – back loop only; YO – yarn over

ESC (extended single crochet): Insert hook in next stitch (BLO), YO, draw up loop. YO, draw through one loop. YO, draw through remaining 2 loops on hook.

Sizing for XS, S, M, L, and XL is included.

572180.name: Reversible PICC Cover
572180.notes_html:
These are for patients, so sanitation is important!
• Each cover should be sealed in its own Ziploc bag.
• Yarn should be fragrance-free, smoke-free and pet hair-free.
• It must be washable.

Small & Medium are the most popular sizes, The length should be no shorter than 5 inches, because the exposed line is the same size for every patient. Modifications are encouraged, as long as the material remains stretchy.
572180.notes:
These are for patients, so sanitation is important!
• Each cover should be sealed in its own Ziploc bag.
• Yarn should be fragrance-free, smoke-free and pet hair-free.
• It must be washable.

Small & Medium are the most popular sizes, The length should be no shorter than 5 inches, because the exposed line is the same size for every patient.  Modifications are encouraged, as long as the material remains stretchy.

587206.name: PICC Crochet Armband
587206.gauge_description: 20 stitches  = 4 inches in single crochet in round
587206.notes_html: Create a fashionable arm cover in a soft yarn to cover a PICC line dressing. A simple tube in cheerful colors can make a person’s day, and only takes a small amount of time.
587206.notes: Create a fashionable arm cover in a soft yarn to cover a PICC line dressing. A simple tube in cheerful colors can make a person's day, and only takes a small amount of time.

users.about_me:
Raveler #4543

I'm a knitty girl, have been since 2001.  My father had just passed away & my mom was just lost.  I asked her to teach me to knit because I wanted her to be doing something, to be involved in.  It worked & now we have a closer relationship than before, both becoming completely obsessed with yarn & knitting!

I have a super fabulous job at Knit Picks - I'm the Outreach Director, where I deal mainly with the exclusive KP collections. It's wonderful to meet so many fantastic designers.

My obsessions other than knitting include reading, sewing, drinking coffee, riding my bike around my beautiful city, volunteering at a local animal shelter, and watching a heck of a lot of baseball.

Raveler #4543

I’m a knitty girl, have been since 2001. My father had just passed away & my mom was just lost. I asked her to teach me to knit because I wanted her to be doing something, to be involved in. It worked & now we have a closer relationship than before, both becoming completely obsessed with yarn & knitting!

I have a super fabulous job at Knit Picks - I’m the Outreach Director, where I deal mainly with the exclusive KP collections. It’s wonderful to meet so many fantastic designers.

My obsessions other than knitting include reading, sewing, drinking coffee, riding my bike around my beautiful city, volunteering at a local animal shelter, and watching a heck of a lot of baseball.

647628.name: Olivia's NICU Hat
647628.gauge_description: 5 stitches and 6 rows = 1 inch in stockinette
647628.notes_html:
In 2014, my youngest daughter spent time in the NICU. She was given a cute hat that allowed her IV to poke out the top so that her little head could still be warm. The staff at our NICU were so fabulous and the support families were so generous that I wanted to give something back. I searched the internet for the pattern, but none was to be found. I designed this hat like the hat we were given to that I could make and donate some hats to the NICU. I ask that you do not sell items from this pattern, it is meant to be free for those people who want to donate or make for personal use.
The hat is knit flat and an easy beginner pattern.

The hat is knit flat and an easy beginner pattern.

pattern_author.name: Danielle Pace
pattern_author.notes:
I have been knitting for since 1998, crocheting since 1988, spinning since 2006, designing since 2007, weaving since 2008 and dying yarn and roving since 2009.

I live in Logan, Utah.  My primary job is being a mom to my 4 little girls one is 10, one is 6, one is 4 and the baby is brand new. My other 3 jobs are working part time at T J Maxx, running my fiber arts booth at the Gardner's Market and teaching spinning lessons at my LYS.

I love anything fiber arts related.

674335.name: Deadpool PICC Line Cuff
674335.notes_html:
This pattern was created for my teen son as he was preparing to undergo chemotherapy. Although I wan’t thrilled with his love of the movie Deadpool, I learned to embrace it since it has become my son’s personal symbol for overcoming cancer. Who can argue with that?

I wrote this pattern as I was creating it and have not tested it since then. Please let me know if you need any clarification or corrections.

Enjoy!

Chart no longer available at this time

Update: The increases in this pattern are not really necessary due to the stretchy yarn. You can still use them but feel free to eliminate them and work the pattern evenly.

I wrote this pattern as I was creating it and have not tested it since then.  Please let me know if you need any clarification or corrections.

Enjoy!

users.about_me: Judy’s Magic Cast On Knitty Tutorial: https://knitty.com/ISSUEspring06/FEATmagiccaston.html

674388.name: Pane Lace with Moon
674388.notes_html:
The last pattern of the “Pane Lace” series is here!! ^_^

For guys who come across this design as first time, this is the last one of the hat in the “Pane Lace” series which I have designed to donate to the local hospital for brain surgery patients.This design also use the same pattern in the body part as the other hat in this series but have different shaping crown.

This hat looks more different than the other hats in this series as I was required to leave the hole at the top of the hat so the IV tube can go through. But some friends said they can use the hat with the hole on top for pulling out the pony ^_^

As this was required for the brain surgery patients which light and soft yarn preferred, then I use the Thai Cotton Bamboo for this project.

You can find the other hat of the “Pane Lace” series in the link following,

Pane Lace with Star:
http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/library/pane-lace-with-star

Pane Lace with Sun:
http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/library/pane-lace-with-sun

Send my best wishes to all the people you knit these hats for ^_^

One of our friend found some error on the pattern of this hat. Please be sure if you have the update version one, revised on July 8, 2016. Thank you!

698356.name: Dialysis Gloves
698356.notes_html:
Errata for basic glove: row 4 should read “repeat rows 2-3.”

This glove has been designed for patients undergoing dialysis. The dialysis procedure causes many patients to become unbearably cold in the arm in which the dialysis is being administered.

The design of the glove has been found to be successful in keeping the patient’s arm and hand comfortable while allowing the nurse administering dialysis access to the veins as necessary throughout the procedure.

The pattern itself is untested by anyone other than the designer. Any questions or suggestions are welcome. The designer has thus far made about 12-14 of these gloves and has been asked for more, hence the publication of this pattern, which will remain free.

Updated for clarification October 17, 2016

Added basic pattern with sc, dc, ch st only.
